name: Chinese Five-Spice Powder
description: This recipe makes about 1/2 cup -- plenty to gift one or two friends. Halve it for single household use.
recipeIngredient: 1  cinnamon/cassia stick, (broken into small pieces (use your fingers))
12  green cardamom pods or 1 medium Chinese black cardamom,

recipeInstructions.text: Toast the spices. Combine the whole spices (everything but the ginger!)  in a small skillet. Set over medium-low heat and cook, stirring frequently, for about 5 minutes, until very fragrant,  popping a tiny bit; some of the fennel seeds should be lightly browned. At that point, pull the skillet off the heat and pour the spices into a bowl to cool. Stir in any ground spices you may be using so may commingle well with the warm, toasted spices.

recipeInstructions.text: Cool, grind, and store. Let the spices cool to room temperature before grinding in 2 or 3 batches in a clean electric grinder dedicated to spices or a spice grinder.
recipeInstructions.name: Cool, grind, and store. Let the spices cool to room temperature before grinding in 2 or 3 batches in a clean electric grinder dedicated to spices or a spice grinder.

recipeInstructions.text: When done, clean the grinder by whirling up a tablespoon of raw rice, and discarding it. Store the Chinese five-spice powder in a jar for up to a year. You may push it to 2 years but if it’s faded in flavor and fragrance, definitely make a new batch.

review.reviewBody: Thanks for the five spice recipe.  Did you make your own ground ginger?  Another mysterious Chinese spice mix is the kind used for  Huà méi/ Xí muội (preserved plums).  I serious don't know what's in it!
Just made this, and it is outstanding.  Thanks for the recipe, Andrea.
Wonderful inspirations - as always! Thank you so very much, Ms. Nguyen, for enlightening our palates over and over again!!!
